resource.chars:
(9) 
The Highest & Lowest Ranges of the Barometer, & the Mean 
of the Barometer & Thermometer at <u>Lunden<\u> in the yer 1724. 
Jan. Feb. Mar. Apr. May June July Aug. Sept. Oct. Nov. Dec. 
High 29,8 29,9 30,[half] 30. [half] 29.9 29.9 29.7 29.9 29.9 30.[half] 30.[half] 30.1[half] 
Mean 29,3 29,2 29,4 29.6 29.4[half] 29.4 29.2[half] 29.5[half] 29.3 29.5 29.5 29.2[half] 
Low 28.8 28.6 28.8 29.1[half] 29.0 28.9 28.8 29.2[half] 28.7 29.[half] 28.9 28.3 
Ther<sup>r<\sup> 24i 37i 21i 6[half] 13s 45s 34s 23s 1[half] 15.i. 30.1 43.i. 
The Barometrical Heights at <u>Petersburgh<\u> A.D. 1724 & 1725. 
Decemb. Januar. Februar March April May June 
High 31,12 31,59 30,36 30,35 29,87 29,99 29.81 
Mean 30,61 29,97 29,32 29,76 29,57 29,67 29,45 
Low 30,11 28,36 28,28 29,18 29,28 29,35 29,10 
<u>Pp 107.<\u> By comparing these two Tables together, it is 
manifest that the <u>Mercurial Ascents<\u> are much 
greater at <u>Petersburgh<\u> than at <u>Lunden<\u>, & that 
the <u>Descents<\u> are nearly the same: so that the 
<u>Range<\u> of the Barometer at <u>Petersburgh<\u> is 3 
inches, 31 hundredth parts; but at <u>Lunden<\u> only 
1 inch & about 8 tenths. 
Of the <u>Winds<\u> & <u>Weather<\u> at <u>Lunden<\u> in 1724. 
In <u>Janua<\u>ry the <u>Winds<\u> were, for the most 
part, about the Westerly & Southerly points, 
& frequently very boisterous. The Weather 
was some Cloudy, some Fair, frequent Rain, 
but no Cold taken notice of till Jan. 30

Mean 30,61 29,97 29,32 29,76 29,57 29,67 29,45 
Low 30,11 28,36 28,28 29,18 29,28 29,35 29,10 
<u>Pp 107.<\u> By comparing these two Tables together, it is 
manifest that the <u>Mercurial Ascents<\u> are much

Of the <u>Winds<\u> & <u>Weather<\u> at <u>Lunden<\u> in 1724. 
In <u>Janua<\u>ry the <u>Winds<\u> were, for the most
